abstract: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again. Proxy fights, once the exclusive domain of investors like Carl C. Icahn, are on the rise. The primary cause, says The New York Times, is easy to spot: “The resurgence of shareholder activism is a direct result of the growth of hedge funds,” Marc Weingarten, a partner at law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, told The Times.
lead_paragraph: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again. Proxy fights, once the exclusive domain of investors like Carl C. Icahn, are on the rise. The primary cause, says The New York Times, is easy to spot: “The resurgence of shareholder activism is a direct result of the growth of hedge funds,” Marc Weingarten, a partner at law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, told The Times.

headline.main: Active Hedge Funds Create New Wealth for Law Firms
